results.name: Triangle T(n,k), 0 < k <= n, T(n,1) = n - 1, T(n,k) = T(n,k-1) + n; read by rows.
comment: This simple triangle arose analyzing f(x) = x/(n + e^(c/x)), for n <> 0. f(x) converges towards a rational number for large values of x, if x is rational. T(n+1,k)/(n+1)^2 equals the fractional portion of f(x) if x is large and restricted to the positive integers, c = 1 and n>=1, whereby the value of the fractional portion changes on a cycle with period n+1 (as k goes from 1 to n+1) for each n in the denominator of f(x). Other, somewhat similar triangles (or repeating fractional patterns) arise with other rational values of n or c, or other rational increments of x (even if a large irrational initial value of x is used).
